title: 105_hr4336
content: Establishment of initiative for food and other assistance for individuals in Indonesia and Southeast Asia affected by the Asian financial crisis. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, in coordination with the Secretary of Agriculture, will establish an initiative for food and other assistance for individuals in Indonesia and Southeast Asia affected by the Asian financial crisis. This initiative will include agricultural commodity distribution technical assistance, agricultural research, extension, farmer-to-farmer, and food assistance programs, as well as support for nongovernmental organizations. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, in coordination with the Secretary of Agriculture, will establish an initiative for food and other assistance for individuals in Indonesia and Southeast Asia affected by the Asian financial crisis. Private voluntary organizations and cooperatives can request funds for food assistance programs through the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954. Requests will be approved or disapproved by the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. The United States Agency for International Development will establish an initiative for food assistance in Indonesia and Southeast Asia, funded with $100,000,000 from the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The program can run for up to 4 years. The United States Agency for International Development will allocate funds from the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to address food, medical, fuel, and other shortages in Indonesia and Southeast Asia. Assistance for Indonesia will be primarily channeled through indigenous nongovernmental or private voluntary organizations. For fiscal year 1999, funds from the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 will be allocated by the United States Agency for International Development to support various initiatives in Indonesia and Southeast Asia. This includes funding for political institutions, transparency in banking and financial institutions, and legal and judicial reforms in the region. For fiscal year 1999, at least $60,000,000 will be allocated for assistance under the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954. The allocated amounts will remain available until expended.
